title: The Europeana Use Case - Multilingual and Semantic Interoperability in Cultural Heritage Information Systems

author: Vivien Petras, Berlin School of Library and Information Science, Humboldt University of Berlin

segmentation: Good afternoon, my international nice name is Vivian Petrus.
My germinative name is Vivian Petrus.
This is another story from the trenches, but it is a little bit different.
It's not about content management.
With apologize to Joomla, it's more about information access.
So we had your piano talk last year and I assume that most of you have heard about the project.

This talk is going to focus on the multilingual applications that we have within this portal, and some of the anecdotal challenges and problems that we have encountered and maybe you have experienced the same.
Or maybe you have a solution for me.
I'd be really happy to talk to you about that so.
Your piano is.
We call it the digital Cultural Heritage Library for Europe.
It is sponsored and funded by the European Commission.
Went online in 2008 with four million digital objects from cultural heritage institutions from all over Europe.
The idea is that if a cultural heritage object is digitized, meaning there exists a picture, a digital picture, or there exist a version of a manuscript that is digital, we want to have it.
We want to aggregate it, and we want to make it available to anyone who wants to search your piano right now.
Currently there is about 26.
Million objects in your piano.
Most of them are images, images of you know, statues, paintings, drawings, manuscripts.
There's lots of old books.
There's lots of recordings of Lithuanian folk music and other stuff.
Um?
We
We are truly multilingual.
This is from last Friday.
This is an overview of the collections.
As you can see, English doesn't even crack the top five.
This is an overview of the collections that are in European are and their associated language.

Now this is interesting because of the most of the objects that are represented in your planner I images so you know what's the language of an image, so it's not the language of the image, is the language of the metadata that describes the image that we are representing here.
Another reason why we are.
Really multilingual, this is from a 10 month lock analysis of European users and you can see about 70% of all our users use their own native language browser.
They also come from Google that uses their own native language bit or without their volition.
Usually Google does that automatically, but when they come to your partner and search for cultural heritage object in about half of the cases.
Evil goal to their own native language objects.
What does that mean?
You know, I'm German, so I'm searching for the bundle gates in Berlin.
I'm finding objects in all kinds of language and I'm going to the German language objects.
We also see that the more content is in your language.
For example, Swedish is actually in fourth place right now.
The languages in European do not represent the languages spoken in Europe, but the languages that their collections are in.
So a lot of the collections come from Germany, so apparently Swedish people really only like Swedish objects.
Because the only click or in 77% they only click on Swedish objects WHI is that?
Do they only want their own cultural heritage?
Or do they only understand?
Works in their own cultural heritage.
That's really important, because if you're looking for an image of I don't know what that image of The Little Mermaid in Copenhagen, for example.
Now I'm talking about dates is not only in a Danish connection, but if you're only looking in your native language then you might miss all the other objects.
And of course in European, are we really really do want to give all access to everyone in all languages?
Let's start with some.
Some of the multilingual solutions that we have applied in your piano and things that we observe.
So first localization everyone does it.
We provide you interface on 31 languages including bus concluding catalane including collision.
Of course, if you look at that screenshot from up above, only a fourth or quarter of your screen estate is actually translated.
That's the static content, although results, dynamic content.
And yes, we do know that there's quantum management systems out there that allow us to do the translations.
But we are cultural heritage institution and translating dynamic content into 31 languages cost money, which we don't have, so this is a resource problem.
But here's another interesting observation.
We observe from the log files that our users seem to think when they click another language that they switch their searching language.
So what happens is somebody searches in Polish.
And we get weird results.
Then you switched the interface language.
Type in the same query in Polish and now expect to get different results.
As anybody seen this on their systems, we don't know how to explain to our users that this is not what's going to happen.
So we have an interaction problem here and I'd be happy to hear solutions from you.
So that's the easiest of our problems.
What else are we?
Doing, of course we are filtering your query results.
You the search results by language and what does that mean?
It's the language of the metadata record, not the language of content.
So here I was searching for Mozart and in the left.
The low corner you see Mozart early symphonies.
I don't take that mode sets early, symphonies have a language.
With the language of music, I guess we should introduce a category, but it appears in one of the categories.
And the other interesting thing that uses always asking us what does multilingual stand for?
Anyone have an idea?
Well, it's those kinds of providers that aggregate more than one type of language.
And we don't know.
So the second highest language interviewer pianos multilingual.
If people always choose their own native language, then all the content in the multilingual category about four million objects.
Never get clicked on, never get search, never get found.

Also provide document translation and as you can see in that screenshot, we're using the Microsoft Translator right now.

This is general machine translation, so it's not domain specific and of course what happens is a lot of weird and interesting things when you don't translate whole sentences, which all of the stochastic machine translation systems are based on.
What you translate single words or phrases that occur in metadata records.
This is this is actually a great example, so this is this is a record in English on the above and it has a weird concept term I see we.
It turns out that I CV actually stands for the category in a special subject classification, but Google Translator.
When I translate that to Danish translates that into integrity control variable.
So we we thought in the beginning that what we would do because this is metadata, right?
It's maybe 100 words on average, we just translate all the contents on all the 31 languages we've solved.
Our information access problem, but if you translate 30 into 31 languages in in.
No, 50% of the cases we get stuff like that then we have a real problem and we've introduced more errors than solution into our document translation.
Last but not least.
Just create translation, so if you cannot translate documents in order to provide all the languages which we see that we can do in the content management systems, we could translate all the price.
Google does set.
We do plan that for this year only, we don't let know how to do this.
Do we simply translate everything into 31 languages?
Well, if I search for manuscripts in French, then I don't want the German manuscript right.
On the other hand, if I search for images, I might do that.
How much user interaction do you allow?
Do you want people to choose which language is this searching?
They obviously want that we see that from a lock fits, we see that from the user behavior that people want to through still language.
Their language is, as we all know, we all speak several languages, so you want to pick several.
But then how do you do that?
Do you present 31 flags in the search interface?
That's horrible, you just choose for the user.
That's horrible.
We don't know yet.
Um?
If you.
Have a system like ours which does not deal with full text but only with metadata records.
Then one thing becomes vitally important and that is to increase your textual content in order to improve the search.
So what we do is semantic enrichment all the link data people in the room know what I'm talking about.
So you basically want to increase the searchable content and how we do.
How do we do this?
We take whatever text we have in our metadata records.
And we look up the simple concepts and phrases in vocabularies that we have and I put them up there.
The concept we look at in Gemma Thesaurus, which is an environmental teasers agents people we look at in DB pedia and so on and so forth.
And then as you can see on the right hand side of the screen, should we Add all the terms that we find 2 record and then we can search in more languages.
This works really well in some cases like here.
So you have a record it has.
Church as a concept and you enrich it automatically and then you have 15 more languages that you can find that object and great.
And then we've got this poisonous India.
You type in.
Reason an you find a photo of an Indian woman in a French collection?
How did that happen?
As you can see this concept term there is indeed owned, which is French for India.
And it turns out that the owned.
In the Jemmott's house is also the Latvian word for gift or poison.
And since we automatically in which it all of a sudden you get poisonous India, and if you search for poison you get Indian woman carrying baskets 'cause that's what we don't want to do.
So here the biggest chat.
Images and this is from a really nice paper that actually looked at only 200 sample records.
With these enrichments, the biggest challenge is the sparsity.
You know if you only have two words, there's not a lot of you can do the quality.
If one of my favorite examples is if you search for Mona Lisa.
You find images that say this is Mona Lisa, but there's no Mona Lisa on the image, so actually, you know we get Wong data all the time and then is all the ambiguities in the vocabularies.
There's the domain.
If you use an environmental teasers then print in German.
Broke could be the graphical print or pressure, and of course the environmental resource translates it back to pressure.
You have a translation problem.
There's the false front problem.
You know when you when you round trip, we go from one language to the other and your cycle round.
Then you arrive at the wrong translation, and then there's also context ambiguity.
Quarter bar could be in Spain or in Argentina and we don't know where it is.
We do have.
Some plans to improve the situation and one of the plants, and I think this was talked about last year, is that we are moving to a new data model.
It's a linked database, linked data based model, which means that we know which vocabularies in which terms to provide us a using and we have direct links to the vocabularies.
So now we don't use one vocabulary that is not domain specific to in which all the records, but we can use the one vocabulary that the provider uses.
So here's an example that works really well.
This is a collection of musical instruments, is actually really nice collection, and they have their own vocabulary, their own multilingual vocabulary of these instruments.
And now we enrich their record with their own vocabulary and all the multilingual terms.
This of course only works as long as we get the vocabulary from the provider, as it is multilingual.
And as we know which vocabulary it is.

All my problems.
And here is an idea how anybody who wants to can play with this theater.

Because Sup Anna is a European project, we moved to an open data model in last September, which means all the data is freely available and we give it to you in two different ways for the link data people, there's RDF file dumps later Sparkle endpoint, but you can also download the whole file dump and I provided.
The link in the second item, but there's also the cultural heritage and clay track, which is an information retrieval evaluation campaign.
So if you have a system that does semantic enrichments, you can try this out.
We're giving you a collection.
We're giving you queries, and you can see how well your investments really are, and there's also a link there.
Just submitting deadline for Chick is April 14th.
If you have any questions, comments, there's my email.
And thank you very much.
